posts.cooked: I’ve been getting a lot of questions in DMs about how much of my elevator code is necessary (original thread: Elevator Subsystem Example Code ), so I figured I would make a specific post about the simplest, most low-level elevator code implementation I could create. This is a single setpoint elevator code, with untuned PID constants. I don’t know how helpful this will be or if it even matters, but I figured more resources can’t be a bad thing!

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: I strongly recommend adding a gravity compensation term.  It doesn’t need to be a whole feedforward object, just a constant added to the PID output before it’s set to the motor controller.  Without that, I wouldn’t call this a proper elevator control setup.
Ah, makes sense! The original code has been updated to reflect that!

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked: I can make an even more minimal implementation in Python with the MagicBot framework.
what if i submit this as all of my team’s comp code? (we use java)

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
Well, it’d be a move in the right direction.

(I’m a Python fan. Especially as a learning language.)
might be better for learning, but how will you thread.sleep for all of auto to mess with FMS ?

posts.name: Ertu
posts.cooked: how do you decide on the correct value for COUNTS_PER_INCH. we are using a neo brushless motor with built in encoder
for my elevator, I just revolutions and measured lol

posts.name: Ertu
posts.cooked: if ours is a double stage elevator. how do we do it? I tried to do it with the smallest rectangle relative to the big one that stays still and my robot doesn’t work correctly(it never stops until it reaches the top where it just goes down). Robot.java (6.0 KB)
could you explain a bit further what you mean?

posts.name: Ertu
posts.cooked: when i press the buttons for the levels. the elevator just goes up until its max place and then falls down. It doesn’t stop where it needs to.
can you smartdashboard print your inbuilt encoder values and tell me them? i’d also love some more of the code if possible

posts.name: Ertu
posts.cooked: I print the encoder values on the driver station. this is pretty much all of my code since we are using a time based robot (the code I gave before was wrong) my encoder values can be found in the file. Robot.java (6.0 KB) )
